citation: Fady Baroudi and Roger-Youssef Akhrass, “Le patriarche Sévère d’Antioche dans la liturgie maronite,” Syriac Orthodox Patriarchal Journal 56 (2018): 1–12.

data.title: Le patriarche Sévère d’Antioche dans la liturgie maronite
data.abstractNote: Avant le milieu du XVe siècle, les Maronites n’avaient attaché presque aucune importance à l’anathème proféré par les Byzantins à l’encontre des Pères non-chalcédoniens, surtout syriaques. Ainsi fêtaient-ils sans complexe la mémoire de Jacques de Saroug, dédiaient des églises à saint Barsaum et priaient à l’aide de l’anaphore de Philoxène de Mabboug. Il en allait de même, semble-t-il, pour Sévère d’Antioche dont le nom apparaît dans des calendriers, des missels et des livres de baptême utilisés autrefois par les Maronites. C’est ce que le présent article s’efforce de montrer à partir des rares manuscrits qui ont échappé aux deux campagnes dévastatrives du délégué apostolique Eliano (1578-1582) venu en Orient purger les manuscrits des Maronites de toute influence « jacobite ».

data.title: Le Cantique d’Élie de Nisibe (975-1046)
data.abstractNote: The Syro-Oriental Metropolitan Bishop Elias of Nisibis (975-1046) was not only a remarkable theologian and also the most important Christian Arab author with regard to Christian-Muslim relations. He was, first of all, a pastor. Among the sapiential works written by our bishop in Arabic we know, for the moment, of just one manuscript of the song intitled Tasbihat Mar Iliyya Mutran Nasibin, which we were able to consult at the Bibliothèque Nationale of Paris. This manuscript is published here for the first time along with a French translation. The Song of Elias of Nisibis, which is part of a prayer book from the Melkite Church, gives us a first insight into the spirituality of Elias, who is especially known for his love of demonstrative syllogism and clarity of language.

bib: Basma, Jaafar, Christos Anagnostopoulos, Sylvain El-Khoury, Antoine Courban, Andrew J. Gienapp, and Kenan Arnautovic. “The Legacy of Syriac-Aramaic Scholars in Transmitting Neurosurgical Knowledge between Antiquity and the Middle Ages.” World Neurosurgery 152 (2021): 71–79.
citation: Jaafar Basma et al., “The Legacy of Syriac-Aramaic Scholars in Transmitting Neurosurgical Knowledge between Antiquity and the Middle Ages,” World Neurosurgery 152 (2021): 71–79.

data.title: The Legacy of Syriac-Aramaic Scholars in Transmitting Neurosurgical Knowledge between Antiquity and the Middle Ages
data.abstractNote: The link between ancient Greek medicine and the Arabic translation period in the 9th Century cannot be understood without studying the contributions of Syriac scholars. With their mastery of Greek and the related Semitic languages of Syriac and Arabic, they initiated a scientific translation process with methods that prevail to this day. In this paper, we reviewed Hunayn Ibn Isshaq’s Ten Treatises on the Eye to elucidate the original contributions of the Syriac physicians to the field of neurological surgery. We analyzed the oldest known diagram of orbital anatomy along with Hunayn’s genuine ideas on the optic nerve anatomy and pathology, optic chiasm, afferent pupillary reflex, and papilledema and venous congestion. We also reviewed the neurosurgical elements found in the Syriac Book of Medicines, including the thought process in localizing neurological deficits based on clinical experience and anatomical dissections, and the earliest recorded description of brachial plexus pathology.
